newsitem.title: UK: Bradford & Bingley buys Mortgage Express.
newsitem.headline: Bradford & Bingley buys Mortgage Express.

text.p: Britain's Bradford & Bingley Building Society said on Friday it had bought Mortgage Express from Lloyds TSB Group for 64 million pounds ($104 million).

The mutually-owned building society said in a statement that Mortgage Express had 26,000 mortgage customers and a mortgage book totalling 1.5 billion pounds. Mortgage Express is based in Barnet, north London.
A Bradford & Bingley spokesman told Reuters that talks on buying Mortgage Express had been going on for three months and the society had beaten off stiff competition to buy the business.

Mortgage Express offered a means of diversification for Bradford & Bingley but in no way diluted its commitment to mutuality, corporate affairs manager Chris Holland said. It will operate as a wholly-owned subsidiary and maintain its brand, head office and staff, he added.

Holland said the move into what are generally accepted to be riskier mortgages for self-employed and contract workers was a sensible step forward for Bradford & Bingley. Problems suffered by the centralised lender in the past were behind it and it was now a profitable business.

Unlike Bradford & Bingley, whose borrowers own the society, Mortgage Express borrowers will not be members. Mortgage Express recently re-entered the specialist lending market, offering products such as buy-to-rent loans, second home finance and negative equity loans. ($ = 0.615 British Pounds)
